thread.section_title: National News -  New York Daily News
thread.title: Flynn could face charges for lying to FBI on Russia
thread.title_full: Flynn could face charges for lying to FBI on Russia

author: DENIS SLATTERY
title: Flynn could face charges for lying to FBI on Russia
text:
Michael Flynn could face charges for lying to FBI, but that’s up to President Trump's Justice Department Flynn could face charges for lying to FBI on Russia NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Thursday, February 16, 2017, 5:31 PM 
Former national security adviser Michael Flynn lied to the FBI about discussing sanctions with a Russian diplomat ahead of President Trump’s inauguration, accord to a new report Thursday. 
The denial could mean legal charges — lying to FBI agents is a felony — but the decision to prosecute rests with Trump’s Department of Justice, according to the Washington Post . 
Flynn for weeks publicly denied that his conversation with Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak involved U.S. sanctions against Russia put in place by the Obama administration. 
The December call was monitored, as is common practice regarding foreign diplomats, and the acting attorney general warned President Trump’s team that they were repeating a falsehood. 
Congressman's refusal to investigate Flynn is wildly out of order 
Press secretary Sean Spicer and Vice President Mike Pence both publicly denied that Flynn had mentioned any sanctions during the call. 
President Trump asked for Flynn’s resignation Monday following another Washington Post report that revealed Flynn misled Pence about the substance of the call. The kerfuffle around Flynn’s resignation comes after a damning report that the FBI also found several top Trump campaign members were in contact with Russia throughout the campaign. (CARLOS BARRIA/REUTERS) 
The FBI interviewed Flynn on Jan. 24, just days after Trump’s inauguration, to ask him about the contents of his call with Kislyak. 
Trump, on Thursday, continued to defend Flynn, calling him a “fine person.” 
President Trump blasts ‘low-life’ leakers in Flynn Russia fiasco 
The President continued to blame the media for Flynn’s fall, not his own actions. 
On Wednesday, the leadership of the Senate Judiciary Committee asked the Department of Justice and the FBI to brief them on the situation that led to the high-profile resignation. 
In a letter addressed to Attorney General Jeff Sessions and FBI Director James Comey, Sens. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) and Diane Feinstein (D-Calif.), the chairman and ranking member of the committee, cite media reports indicating the involvement of the Justice Department and the FBI in the circumstances leading up to Flynn's resignation. Sergey Kislyak, Russia's ambassador to the US speaks with reporters following his address on the Syrian situation, Friday, Sept. 6, 2013, at the Center for the National Interest in Washington. (AP Photo/Cliff Owen) (Cliff Owen/AP) 
“Accordingly, we request that individuals with specific knowledge of these issues from both the FBI and Justice Department brief Committee Members and staff,” reads the letter. “We similarly request copies of the transcripts of Mr. Flynn’s intercepted calls and the FBI report summarizing the intercepted calls referenced in the media.” 
Trump casually muses on ‘nuclear holocaust,’ yells at reporters 
The kerfuffle around Flynn’s resignation comes after a damning report that the FBI also found several top Trump campaign members were in contact with Russia throughout the campaign. 
Trump appointed Attorney General Jeff Sessions has brushed off calls that he recuse himself from any investigation involving contact between Trump’s close aides and Russian operatives. 
In a recent interview with the Daily Caller, Flynn said he didn’t discuss “sanctions” but did discuss the Obama administration’s expulsion of 35 Russian diplomats, which were part of the sanctions package it announced on Dec. 29 after it was determined that Moscow meddled in the U.S. presidential election. Tags:
